message_1: A particle is described by a wave function given by $u(x,t)=\frac{3}{2}\text{sech}^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)$. Find the velocity and acceleration of the particle.
message_2:
To find the velocity and acceleration of the particle, we need to find the first and second time derivatives of the wave function $u(x,t)$.

First, let's find the first time derivative, which represents the velocity of the particle:

$$\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left[\frac{3}{2}\text{sech}^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\right]$$

To do this, we'll use the chain rule:

$$\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \frac{3}{2} \cdot 2 \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot (-\text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)) \cdot \frac{-4}{2}$$

Simplifying, we get:

$$\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = 6 \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)$$

Now, let's find the second time derivative, which represents the acceleration of the particle:

$$\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left[6 \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\right]$$

This is a bit more complicated, so we'll use the product rule and chain rule together:

$$\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = 6 \cdot \left[\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left(\text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\right)\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) + \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\right]$$

Now, we'll find the derivatives of the individual terms:

$$\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left(\text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\right) = 2 \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot (-\text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)) \cdot \frac{-4}{2}$$

Simplifying, we get:

$$\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left(\text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\right) = 8 \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)$$

Next, we'll find the derivative of the second term:

$$\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) = \text{sech}^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \frac{-4}{2}$$

Simplifying, we get:

$$\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) = -2 \cdot \text{sech}^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)$$

Now, we can plug these derivatives back into the expression for the second time derivative:

$$\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = 6 \cdot \left[8 \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) + \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot (-2 \cdot \text{sech}^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right))\right]$$

Simplifying, we get:

$$\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = 6 \cdot \left[8 \cdot \text{sech}^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) - 2 \cdot \text{sech}^4\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\right]$$

So, the velocity of the particle is given by:

$$v(x,t) = 6 \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) \cdot \text{sech}\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)$$

And the acceleration of the particle is given by:

$$a(x,t) = 6 \cdot \left[8 \cdot \text{sech}^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\tanh^2\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right) - 2 \cdot \text{sech}^4\left(\frac{x-4t}{2}\right)\right]$$
